{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Nepenthes'' literature}} [[File:Nepenthesbongso.jpg|thumb|A hand-coloured lithograph of ''[[Nepenthes bongso|N. bongso]]'' from [[Pieter Willem Korthals]]'s "[[Over het geslacht Nepenthes|Over het geslacht ''Nepenthes'']]" of 1839, generally regarded as the first monograph on the genus.Clarke, C.M. 1997. ''[[Nepenthes of Borneo]]''. Natural History Publications (Borneo), Kota Kinabalu.Phillipps, A., A. Lamb & C.C. Lee 2008. ''[[Pitcher Plants of Borneo]]''. Second Edition. Natural History Publications (Borneo), Kota Kinabalu.]] This '''list of ''Nepenthes'' literature''' is a listing of major published works dealing with the tropical [[pitcher plant]]s of the [[genus]] ''[[Nepenthes]]''. It includes specialised standalone publications and [[Biological classification|taxonomic]] [[monograph]]s released as part of larger works, but excludes regular [[academic journal|journal]] and [[magazine]] articles. Unless otherwise indicated, all information on individual publications is sourced from them directly. Works are listed chronologically by year of first publication. __TOC__ {{-}} ==Standalone publications== This list includes all works published as standalone [[book]]s or booklets, with the exception of [[children's literature]], which is listed separately [[#Children's literature|below]]. {| class="sortable wikitable" ! Name !! Author(s) !! Year !! Language !! Publisher !! Pages !! Additional information !! Reviews |- | {{nihongo|''History of Nepenthes''
|ウツボカヅラの歴史|Utsubokadzura no rekishi}}[http://www.honda-e.com/A05_CP%20Book%20Library/CPBooks_Large/CPBook_NepenKusakabe.htm History of Nepenthes]. Carnivorous Plants / Insectivorous Plants in the Wilderness. || [[Isamu Kusakabe]] || 1961 || [[Japanese language|Japanese]] || [[Insectivorous Plant Society]] || 54 || special issue no. 3 of the ''[[Journal of Insectivorous Plant Society]]'' || |- | ''[[Nepenthes of Mount Kinabalu]]'' || [[Shigeo Kurata]] || 1976 || English || [[Sabah National Parks Trustees]] || 80 || significantly contributed to popular interest in ''Nepenthes''Shivas, R.G. 1984. ''Pitcher Plants of Peninsular Malaysia & Singapore''. Maruzen Asia, Kuala Lumpur. || see [[Nepenthes of Mount Kinabalu|article]] |- | ''The Pitcher Plant: Nepenthes khasiana'' || [[Renu Prova Momin Bordoloi]] || 1977 || English || Dutta Baruah || 59 || part of the ''Carnivorous Plants of North East India'' series; 5 pages of plates not included in page count || |- | ''Pitcher Plants of Peninsular Malaysia & Singapore'' || [[Roger Shivas]] || 1984 || English || Maruzen Asia || xii + 58 || 24 pages of plates not included in page count || "It was the author's intention to make this book serve as a field guide and he succeeded in this by giving us good closeup pictures of upper, lower and sometimes intermediate pitchers of all 12 species that are described. Although the book is small, and ideal for field use, it does not lack any of the essential information that one needs to use in finding these plants and admiring them."[Anonymous] 1984. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''13'''(2): 54. |- | {{nihongo|''The Grief Vanishing – Nepenthes''[http://www.sarracenia.com/faq/faq6010a.html Ivo's Book List]. The Carnivorous Plant FAQ. ([http://ivo.koudela.sweb.cz/books.txt updated list])
|無憂草 – Nepenthes|Muyū kusa – Nepenthes}} || [[Tetsuya Oikawa]] || 1992 || [[Japanese language|Japanese]] || Parco Co. || 66 || part of the ''Jungle Books'' series || "1 to 9 photos of each mentioned species, information on morphology and functions of ''Nepenthes''. The photos are so beautiful that at least ''Nepenthes'' enthusiasts should have this book." |- | ''[[Pitcher-Plants of Borneo]]'' || [[Anthea Phillipps]] & [[Anthony Lamb]] || 1996 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || x + 171 || strongly focused on botanical and horticultural history; mainly illustrated with watercolour paintings by Susan M. Phillipps || see [[Pitcher-Plants of Borneo|article]] |- | ''[[Nepenthes of Borneo]]'' || [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]] || 1997, 2006
(reprint) || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || xii + 207 || ecological and taxonomic monograph || see [[Nepenthes of Borneo|article]] |- | ''[[Nepenthes of Sumatra and Peninsular Malaysia]]'' || [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]] || 2001 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || x + 326 || ecological and taxonomic monograph; 1 new species described || see [[Nepenthes of Sumatra and Peninsular Malaysia|article]] |- | ''A Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Sabah'' || [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]] || 2001 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || iv + 40 || field guide || "The photos are simply incredible, and the book covers important information such as natural habitats. Indeed, it is somewhat like a condensed version of "''Nepenthes'' of Borneo", but rewritten in less scientific language."Catalani, M. 2003. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''32'''(1): 10. |- | ''A Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Peninsular Malaysia'' || [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]] || 2002 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || iv + 32 || field guide || "As usual for one of Clarke's books, the text is concise, well written and accurate. But overshadowing the text is the photography, which is truly beautiful as well as illustrative of the essential characters of each species and hybrid."Rice, B. 2003. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''32'''(4): 112. |- | ''Borneo: Its Mountains and Lowlands with their Pitcher Plants'' || [[Hugo Steiner]] || 2002 || English || Toihaan Publishing Company || viii + 136 || mainly illustrated with photographs taken by the author between 1992 and 2002 || "People looking for an interesting but not too technical or scientific work on Borneo and its pitcher plants would especially benefit from this book. [...] The aesthetic aspect remains very good despite two or three low quality photographs [...]"Hartmeyer, S.R.H. 2003. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''32'''(3): 68.{{de icon}} Hartmeyer, S.R.H. 2003. Ein neues Buch zum Thema ''Nepenthes'' in englischer Sprache. ''[[Das Taublatt]]'' '''47'''(3): 22–23. |- | ''Pitcher Plants of Sarawak'' || [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]] & [[Ch'ien Lee]] || 2004 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || vi + 81 || pocket field guide; mainly illustrated with photographs by [[Ch'ien Lee]] || "This is a wonderful introduction to the species that grow in this area and is in full colour. With an introduction to ''Nepenthes'', the 25 species plus an environmental examination it whets your appetite to want to visit this area or at least grow the plants."[Anonymous] 2005. {{cite web |url= http://www.vcps.au.com/journals/75_Mar_2005Public.pdf |title= A new ''Nepenthes'' book. |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110707185305/http://www.vcps.au.com/journals/75_Mar_2005Public.pdf |archivedate= 2011-07-07 |df= }} ''[[Victorian Carnivorous Plant Society Journal]]'' '''75''': 18.
"As usual with Clarke's books, the photographs are excellent." |- | ''[[The Nepenthaceae of the Netherlands Indies]]'' || [[B. H. Danser]] || 2006 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || vi + 206 || reprint of the 1928 monograph; includes 15-page introduction by [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]]Clarke, C.M. 2006. Introduction. In: Danser, B.H. ''[[The Nepenthaceae of the Netherlands Indies]]''. Natural History Publications (Borneo), Kota Kinabalu. pp. 1–15. || see [[The Nepenthaceae of the Netherlands Indies|article]] |- | ''A Field Guide to the Nepenthes of Sumatra'' || [[Hernawati]] & [[Pitra Akhriadi]] || 2006 || English || PILI-NGO Movement || xiv + 94 || field guide; result of research program funded by [[BP]] || "[...] a short book presenting basic information on thirty-one Sumatran taxa [...] The quality of the paper, printing and images is perhaps a little low, but given the very meagre funds available to produce this book, this is understandable."Clarke, C. 2007. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''36'''(3): 72. |- | ''Nepenthes: Kantong Semar Yang Unik'' || [[Muhammad Mansur]] || 2006 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || Penebar Swadaya || iv + 100 || || |- | ''Petunjuk Praktis Perawatan Nepenthes''[http://perpuskabpkl.com/index.php?p=show_detail&id=3913 Petunjuk Praktis Perawatan Nepenthes] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130828005517/http://perpuskabpkl.com/index.php?p=show_detail&id=3913 |date=2013-08-28 }}. Perpustakaan Umum - Kabupaten Pekalongan. || [[Frankie Handoyo]] & [[Maloedyn Sitanggang]] || 2006 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || AgroMedia Pustaka || vi + 66 || cultivation guide || |- | ''Trubus Info Kit: Nepenthes'' || [[Onny Untung]] (chief editor) || 2006 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || PT Trubus Swadaya || iv + 284 || strongly focused on cultivation; English [[e-book]] also available || |- | ''Budi Daya Ex-Situ Nepenthes: Kantong Semar nan Eksotis''[https://books.google.com/books?id=xLCT_oon--sC BUDI DAYA EX-SITU NEPENTHES, Kantong Semar nan Eksotis]. Google Books. || [[Arie Wijayani Purwanto]] || 2007 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || Kanisius || 60 || cultivation guide || |- | ''Entuyut (Nepenthes) asal Kalimantan Barat''{{id icon}} [http://www.kalbariana.net/entuyut-nepenthes-asal-kalimantan-barat Entuyut (Nepenthes) asal Kalimantan Barat] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130827030627/http://www.kalbariana.net/entuyut-nepenthes-asal-kalimantan-barat |date=2013-08-27 }}. Perpustakaan Deposit Kalimantan Barat. || [[Agustina Listiawati]] & [[Chairani Siregar]] || 2008 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || Untan Press || 88 || government publication || |- | ''[[Pitcher Plants of Borneo]]'', Second Edition || [[Anthea Phillipps]], [[Anthony Lamb]] & [[Ch'ien Lee]] || 2008 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || viii + 298 || much expanded second edition; strongly focused on botanical and horticultural history; includes many photographs by [[Ch'ien Lee]] || see [[Pitcher Plants of Borneo|article]] |- | {{lang|th|ร้อยพรรณพฤกษา ไม้กินแมลง หม้อข้าวหม้อแกงลิง}} || [[Suwarun Suphawut]] || 2009{{Ref_label|A|a|none}} || [[Thai language|Thai]] || เศรษฐศิลป์ || 112 || strongly focused on cultivation and horticultural hybrids || |- | ''[[Pitcher Plants of the Old World]]'' (2 volumes) || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] || 2009 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || xvi + 1399 || also covers ''[[Cephalotus|Cephalotus follicularis]]''; 1 new species described || see [[Pitcher Plants of the Old World|article]] |- | ''The Malaysian Nepenthes: Evolutionary and Taxonomic Perspectives'' || [[Chris Thorogood]] || 2010 || English || Nova Science Publishers || vi + 158 || part of the ''Botanical Research and Practices Series'' || |- | ''Nepenthes della Thailandia: Diario di viaggio'' || [[Marcello Catalano]] || 2010 || [[Italian language|Italian]] || self-published || 207 || travel diary; 4 new species described || "In a narrative style that only Italians master (“se non è vero, è ben trovato”), the author describes his remarkable experience from roughly a decade of training and research both at herbaria and in the field. [...] The diversity of the genus in Thailand as featured in the present book is far greater than expressed by any previous author."Schlauer, J. 2010. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''39'''(2): 61. |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of the Philippines'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Victor B. Amoroso]] || 2011 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 61 || field guide[Anonymous] 2012. VCPS News: three new ''Nepenthes'' books. ''[[Victorian Carnivorous Plant Society Journal]]'' '''103''': 5. || |- | ''[[New Nepenthes: Volume One]]'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] || 2011 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || xiv + 595 || 7 new species described; includes accounts of new discoveries since 2009 publication of ''[[Pitcher Plants of the Old World]]'' || |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Sulawesi'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Alastair Robinson]] || 2012 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 49 || field guide || |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Borneo'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Alastair Robinson]] || 2012 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 101 || field guide || |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Australia and New Guinea'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Alastair Robinson]] || 2012 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 59 || field guide || |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Peninsular Malaysia and Indochina'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Alastair Robinson]] || 2012 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 59 || field guide || |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Sumatra and Java'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Alastair Robinson]] || 2012 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 91 || field guide || |- | ''Kantong Semar Mirabilis (Nepenthes mirabilis Druce) dan Teknik Budidayanya''[http://perpustakaan.krbogor.lipi.go.id/digilib_krb/index.php?p=show_detail&id=1427 Kantong Semar Mirabilis (Nepenthes mirabilis Druce) dan Teknik Budidayanya]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Digital Library - Bogor Botanic Gardens. || [[Tri Handayani]], [[Yupi Isnaini]] & [[Yuzammi]] || 2012 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || Pusat Konservasi Tumbuhan Kebun Raya Bogor - LIPI || iii + 77 || part of the ''Pendayagunaan Tumbuhan Berpotensi'' series (no. 1) || |- | ''Mengenal Kantong Semar Adrianii''[http://perpustakaan.krbogor.lipi.go.id/digilib_krb/index.php?p=show_detail&id=1395 Mengenal Kantong Semar Adrianii]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Digital Library - Bogor Botanic Gardens. || [[Tri Handayani]], [[Hartutiningsih-M. Siregar]], [[Melani Kurnia Rismawati]] & [[Hary Wawangningrum]] || 2012 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || Pusat Konservasi Tumbuhan Kebun Raya Bogor - LIPI || v + 54 || part of the ''Pendayagunaan Tumbuhan Berpotensi'' series (no. 4) || |} ==Monographs published as part of larger works== This list includes major monographs that were ''not'' released as standalone publications. In the case of journal articles and papers, the parent publication is indicated in brackets. Only the primary [[prose|prosaic]] language is listed for each publication, although many of the earlier monographs also include substantial portions of [[Latin]] text in the form of taxon descriptions. Some of the taxa [[Species description|formally described]] in these monographs are not considered taxonomically valid today. {| class="sortable wikitable" ! Name !! Author(s) !! Year !! Language !! Format !! Pages !! Additional information !! Reviews |- | "[[Over het geslacht Nepenthes|Over het geslacht ''Nepenthes'']]" || [[Pieter Willem Korthals]] || 1839 || [[Dutch language|Dutch]] || part of ''Verhandelingen over de Natuurlijke Geschiedenis der Nederlandsche overzeesche bezittingen'' || 44 || generally regarded as the first monograph on ''Nepenthes''; 3 new species described || |- | "Über die Gattung ''Nepenthes'' besonders in Rücksicht auf ihre physiologische Eigenthümlichkeit" || [[Ernst Wunschmann]] || 1872 || [[German language|German]] || doctoral thesis ([[Humboldt University of Berlin|Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität Berlin]]); published by Buchdruckerei von Gustav Schade (Otto Francke) || 50 || sometimes considered the first monograph on ''Nepenthes'' || |- | "[[Nepenthaceae (1873 monograph)|Nepenthaceae]]" || [[Joseph Dalton Hooker]] || 1873 || [[Latin]] || part of the seventeenth volume of ''[[Prodromus Systematis Naturalis Regni Vegetabilis]]'' || 16 || 7 new species described; primarily focused on new discoveries from northern Borneo || |- | "[[Die Gattung Nepenthes|Die Gattung ''Nepenthes'']]" || [[Günther Beck von Mannagetta und Lerchenau]] || 1895 || [[German language|German]] || journal article (''Wiener Illustrirte Garten-Zeitung'') || 46 || published in 4 parts; 4 new species described; 1 new species combination || |- | "[[Nepenthaceae (1908 monograph)|Nepenthaceae]]" || [[John Muirhead Macfarlane]] || 1908 || English || part of ''[[Das Pflanzenreich]]'' || 91 || 8 new species described; includes detailed accounts of structure, anatomy, and development || see [[Nepenthaceae (1908 monograph)|article]] |- | "[[The Nepenthaceae of the Netherlands Indies]]" || [[B. H. Danser]] || 1928 || English || journal article (''Bulletin du Jardin Botanique de Buitenzorg'') || 190 || widely considered the most important monograph on ''Nepenthes'';McPherson, S.R. 2009. ''[[Pitcher Plants of the Old World]]''. 2 volumes. Redfern Natural History Productions, Poole.Clarke, C.M. 2001. ''[[Nepenthes of Sumatra and Peninsular Malaysia]]''. Natural History Publications (Borneo), Kota Kinabalu. 17 new species described || see [[The Nepenthaceae of the Netherlands Indies|article]] |- | "Nepenthaceae" || [[Hermann Harms]] || 1936 || [[German language|German]] || part of ''Die natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien'' || 38 || similar to Danser's treatment || |- | "''Nepenthes'' di Sumatera: The genus ''Nepenthes'' of the Sumatra Island" || [[Rusjdi Tamin]] & [[Mitsuru Hotta]] || 1986 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || paper (''Diversity and Dynamics of Plant Life in Sumatra'', Part 1) || 35 || 3 new species described (originally ''[[nomen nudum|nomina nuda]]'' as they were published without Latin diagnoses) || |- | "Pitcher-plants of East Malaysia and Brunei" || [[Anthea Phillipps]] & [[Anthony Lamb]] || 1988 || English || journal article (''Nature Malaysiana'') || 20 || includes 80 colour photographs || |- | "[[An account of Nepenthes in New Guinea|An account of ''Nepenthes'' in New Guinea]]" || [[Matthew Jebb]] || 1991 || English || journal article (''Science in New Guinea'') || 48 || includes a survey of pitcher prey assemblages || see [[An account of Nepenthes in New Guinea|article]] |- | "[[A skeletal revision of Nepenthes (Nepenthaceae)|A skeletal revision of ''Nepenthes'' (Nepenthaceae)]]" || [[Matthew Jebb]] & [[Martin Cheek]] || 1997 || English || journal article (''[[Blumea (journal)|Blumea]]'') || 106 || 6 new species described; 1 new species combination || see [[A skeletal revision of Nepenthes (Nepenthaceae)|article]] |- | "[[Nepenthaceae (2001 monograph)|Nepenthaceae]]" || [[Martin Cheek]] & [[Matthew Jebb]] || 2001 || English || fifteenth volume of ''[[Flora Malesiana]]'' || iv + 157 || only covers species native to [[Malesia]] || see [[Nepenthaceae (2001 monograph)|article]] |} ==Children's literature== {| class="sortable wikitable" ! Name !! Author(s) !! Year !! Language !! Publisher !! Pages !! Additional information !! Reviews |- | ''Jack & the Carnivorous Pitcher Plant'' || [[Tan Wee Kiat]] & [[Amy Sabrielo]] || 1999 || English || Landmark Books || 83 || illustrated by Lesley Gan; dust jacket folds out into a ''Nepenthes''-themed board game || |- | ''Singapore Heritage: the Raffles Pitcher Plant'' || [[Tan Wee Kiat]] || 2003 || English || Singapore Philatelic Museum || 16 || covers stamps, currency and phone cards featuring ''Nepenthes''; single-page foreword and appendix not included in page count || |} ==Notes== {{refbegin}} :a.{{Note_label|A|a|none}}Year 2552 in the [[Thai solar calendar]]. {{refend}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.sarracenia.com/faq/faq6010a.html Ivo's Book List] at The Carnivorous Plant FAQ ([http://ivo.koudela.sweb.cz/books.txt updated list]) {{Nepenthes monographs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nepenthes literature, List of}} [[Category:Nepenthes literature| *]] [[Category:Literature lists|Nepenthes literature]]

revision.comment: copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]]; url trimming of identifying info per[[WP:LINKSTOAVOID]] and [[Template:Citation_Style_documentation#url|Citation Style]]
revision.text:
[[File:Bradshaw rock paintings.jpg|thumb|280px|In this [[Bradshaw rock paintings|Bradshaw rock painting]] from Australia the artist portrays tasseled costumed figures in various poses or actions.]] This is a descriptive '''list of art from the [[Stone Age]]''', the period of [[prehistory]] characterised by the widespread use of [[stone tool]]s. This page contains, by sheer volume of the artwork discovered, a very incomplete list of the works of the painters, sculptors, and other artists who created what we now call prehistoric art. For fuller lists see [[Art of the Upper Paleolithic]], [[Art of the Middle Paleolithic]], and [[:Category:Prehistoric art]] and its many sub-categories.
== Sculpture == [[File:F07 0054.Ma.JPG|thumb|300px|right|''[[Bison Licking Insect Bite]]'', in carved [[antler]], National Museum of Prehistory, [[Les Eyzies-de-Tayac-Sireuil]]]] * [[Adam of Govrlevo]], or "Adam of Macedonia". At more than 7,000 years old, the sculpture is the oldest artifact found in the [[Republic of Macedonia]]. The artist depicts a sitting male body, and shows details of his spine, ribs, navel, and phallus. The piece is now exhibited in the [[Museum of the City of Skopje|Skopje City Museum]]. * [[Ain Sakhri lovers]], an 11,000 year-old figurine from the [[Ain Sakhri]] caves near [[Bethlehem]], is the oldest known representation of humans engaged in sex.<ref name=ahotw>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ahistoryoftheworld/objects/vNEwNR8rSzGPSwSn3yeJwA A History of the World -7], BBC.co.uk, accessed July 2010</ref> It is now displayed in the [[British Museum]]. * [[Bird stone]]s (5,000 to 2,500 years old) are portable bird-shaped stone sculptures created by generations of North American sculptors. * ''[[Bison Licking Insect Bite]]'', an app. 15,000-year-old carved and engraved fragment of a [[spear-thrower]] made of [[reindeer]] antler, the piece depicts a member of the now extinct Bison species [[steppe wisent]]. The artist carved the bison's head turned to its right and licking itself as if bitten by an insect.<ref>[http://musee-prehistoire-eyzies.fr/en/collection/tid-4/cid-5/collection-bison-se-lechant, "Collections", National Museum of Prehistory] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150430045958/http://musee-prehistoire-eyzies.fr/en/collection/tid-4/cid-5/collection-bison-se-lechant%2C |date=2015-04-30 }} in Les Eyzies-de-Tayac-Sireuil (in French)</ref> It's exhibited in the National Museum of Prehistory in [[Les Eyzies-de-Tayac-Sireuil]], not far from where it was found. * [[Elk's Head of Huittinen]] is an eight to 9,000 year old sculpture exhibited at the [[National Museum of Finland]]. * ''[[Löwenmensch figurine|Löwenmensch]]'', or ''Lion Man'', is an [[ivory]] [[sculpture]] that is both the oldest known [[zoomorphic|animal-shaped]] sculpture in the world and, at 40,000 years,<ref>Martin Bailey [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Ice-Age-iLion-Mani-is-worlds-earliest-figurative-sculpture/28595 Ice Age Lion Man is world's earliest figurative sculpture] ''The Art Newspaper'', Jan 31, 2013, accessed Feb 01, 2013</ref> the oldest known uncontested example of figurative art. The sculpture is now housed in the [http://www.tourismus.ulm.de/tourismus/en/sehenswert/museen_und_co/ulmer_museum/ulmer_museum.php Ulm Museum] in [[Ulm]], Germany. * [[Mammoth spear thrower]], a [[spear thrower]] carved by the artist into the form of a [[Mammoth]], was discovered at the [[rock shelter]] of [[Montastruc, Tarn-et-Garonne]], France. It is now exhibited in the British Museum. [[File:Magdalenian horse.jpg|thumb|280px|Magdalenian Horse, c. 15,000 BCE, [[Musée d'Archéologie Nationale]], France]] * [[Montastruc decorated stone (Palart 518)|Montastruc decorated stone]] is an app. 13,000 years old scratched or engraved human figure on a piece of limestone – which appears to be female –used as a lamp. From Courbet Cave, France, it now resides in the British Museum. * [[Baton fragment (Palart 310)|Perforated baton with low relief horse]] is from [[Abri de la Madeleine]], an overhanging cliff situated near [[Tursac]] in France, and is stored in the [[British Museum]]. * [[Pinhole Cave Man]], or Pin Hole Cave Man, has become the common name for an engraving of a human figure on a [[woolly rhinoceros]] rib bone. The piece was found in Pin Hole Cave, [[Creswell Crags]], Derbyshire, England, and is now in the [[British Museum]]. * [[Robin Hood Cave Horse]] (previously known as the ''Ochre Horse''). This fragment of rib that the artist engraved with a [[horse]]'s head was discovered in the Robin Hood Cave in [[Creswell Crags]], Derbyshire, England. It is the only animal-related Upper [[Paleolithic]] [[portable art]]work ever found in Britain.<ref name="British Museum">{{cite web |url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_prb/h/horse_engraving_on_bone.aspx |title=British Museum – Horse engraving on bone |first= |last=British Museum |work=britishmuseum.org |year=2011 |accessdate=14 October 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016133100/http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_prb/h/horse_engraving_on_bone.aspx |archive-date=2011-10-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="MuseumSieveking1987">{{cite book|author1=British Museum|author2=Ann Sieveking|title=A catalogue of palaeolithic art in the British Museum|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DtCfAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA112|accessdate=14 October 2011|year=1987|publisher=Published for the Trustees of the British Museum by British Museum Publications|isbn=978-0-7141-1376-0|pages=112–}}</ref> ''Robin Hood Cave Horse'' is now housed in the [[British Museum]]. * The [[Shigir Idol]], a 11,000 years old wooden sculpture, resides in the Historic Exhibition Museum in [[Yekaterinburg]], Russia. * ''[[Swimming Reindeer]]'' is a 13,000-year-old ([[Magdalenian]]) sculpture of two swimming reindeer ornately carved from the tusk of a mammoth. The sculpture is now in the [[British Museum]]. * The [[Alunda moose]] is a Neolithic artistic stone axe c.2000 B.C. that was found in Uppland, Sweden. It is displayed in the [[Swedish History Museum]]. * [[Stone circle]] ** [[List of stone circles]] ** [[Stone circles in the British Isles and Brittany]]
== [[Cave paintings]] and other [[rock art]] == [[File:Chauvethorses.jpg|thumb|250px|The artist depicts a group of wild or domesticated horses. (from [[Chauvet Cave]] in France)]] [[File:Cave of Altamira and Paleolithic Cave Art of Northern Spain-110113.jpg|thumb|[[Cave of Altamira and Paleolithic Cave Art of Northern Spain|Cave of Altamira and Paleolithic Cave Art]] of Northern Spain]] * In September 2018, scientists reported the discovery of the earliest known drawing by ''[[Homo sapiens]]'', which is estimated to be 73,000 years old, much earlier than the 43,000 years old artifacts understood to be the earliest known modern human drawings found previously.<ref name="NYT-20180912">{{cite news |last=St. Fleur |first=Nicholas|title=Oldest Known Drawing by Human Hands Discovered in South African Cave |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/12/science/oldest-drawing-ever-found.html |date=12 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=15 September 2018 }}</ref> * The [[Petroglyph]] (incised rock art) article features a [[Petroglyph#List of petroglyph sites|list of petroglyph sites]] * [[Cave of Altamira|Altamira cave]] (Spain) – in 1879 the first prehistoric paintings and drawings were discovered in this cave, which soon became famous for their depth of color and depictions of animals, hands, and abstract shapes. * [[Bhimbetka rock shelters]] (India) – the shelters, decorated with art from 30,000 years ago, contain the oldest evidence of artists exhibiting their work on the Indian sub-continent. * [[Bradshaw rock paintings]] (Australia) – Aboriginal artists painted well over a million paintings in this site in the [[Kimberley region of Western Australia|Kimberley]], many of human figures ornamented with accessories such as bags, [[tassel]]s and headdresses.<ref name="Don">Donaldson, Mike [https://www.scribd.com/doc/62208928/Bradshaw-Figures-in-Cave-Art ''The Gwion or Bradshaw art style of Australia's Kimberley region is undoubtedly among the earliest rock art in the country –but is it Pleistocene?''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305181051/https://www.scribd.com/doc/62208928/Bradshaw-Figures-in-Cave-Art |date=2016-03-05 }} (free download) L'art pléistocène en Australie (Pré-Actes) [[International Federation of Rock Art Organizations|IFRAO]] Congress, September 2010 p. 4.</ref> These artworks are well over 20,000 years old. * [[Caves in Cantabria|Cantabria cave]] (Spain) * [[Çatalhöyük]] (Turkey) – probably the best preserved large [[Neolithic]] site, its artwork includes [[murals]], [[figurine]]s, and depictions of animals. The ''[[Seated Woman of Çatalhöyük]]'' was found here. * [[Chauvet Cave]] (France) – some of the earliest cave paintings known, and considered among the most important prehistoric art sites. * [[Cave of Chufín|Chufin cave]] (Spain) – small cave with engravings, stick figures, and artwork schematically portraying red deer, goats and cattle. * [[Coliboaia Cave|Coliboaia cave]] ([[Romania]]) contains the oldest known cave paintings of [[Central Europe]], radiocarbon dated to 32,000 and 35,000 BP, corresponding to the Aurignacian and Gravettian cultures of the Paleolithic period. * [[Cuciulat Cave|Cuciulat cave]] (Romania) features several red paintings of animals, including horses and felines, which are about 12,000 years old. These were the first manifestations of this kind known in Central Europe. * [[Cueva de las Manos|Cueva de las Manos (Cave of Hands)]] (Argentina) – a series of caves exhibiting hundreds of outlines of human hands, hunting scenes, and animals painted 13,000 to 9,000 years ago. * [[Prehistoric Rock-Art Site of the Côa Valley|Côa Valley]] (Portugal) – artists engraved thousands of drawings of horses and other animal, human and abstract figures in open-air artwork completed 22,000 to 10,000 years ago. * [[Cosquer Cave]] (France) – [[hand stencils]] from 27,000 years ago, and 19,000-year-old animal drawings that portray bison, [[ibex]], horses, [[Pinniped|seals]] and what may be [[auk]]s and [[jellyfish]], showcase this gallery. * [[Draa River#History|Draa River]] (Morocco) [[File:Lascaux painting.jpg|thumb|300px|A 16,000-year-old masterwork from the [[Lascaux cave]] in France]] [[File:Bubalus Tin Taghirt.jpg|thumb|Rock carving of [[Pelorovis antiquus]] at [[Tassili n'Ajjer]], southern Algeria]] * [[Cave of El Castillo|El Castillo cave]], one of the [[Caves of Monte Castillo|Monte Castillo caves]] (Spain) – contains decorations in [[red ochre]] paint which has been blown onto the walls in the forms of hand stencils as long as 37,000 years ago, and painted dots. One faint red dot has been dated to 40,800 years ago, making it the oldest dated [[cave art|cave decoration]] in the world.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.1219957 | volume=336 | title=U-Series Dating of Paleolithic Art in 11 Caves in Spain | year=2012 | journal=Science | pages=1409–1413 | last1 = Pike | first1 = A. W. G.}}</ref><ref>[https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn21925?full=true "Oldest confirmed cave art is a single red dot"] by Michael Marshall, ''[[New Scientist]]'', 23 June 2012, pp. 10-11.</ref> It is 5,000-10,000 years older than caves so-far found in France.<ref name="Clottes214">{{cite book |last=Clottes |first=Jean |authorlink= Jean Clottes |others=Paul G. Bahn (translator) |title=Chauvet Cave: The Art of Earliest Times |year=2003 |publisher=University of Utah Press |isbn=0-87480-758-1}} Translation of ''La Grotte Chauvet, l'art des origins'', Éditions du Seuil, 2001, p. 214.</ref><ref name=bbc_reddot>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-18449711 |title=Red dot becomes 'oldest cave art' |work=BBC News |last=Amos |first=Jonathan |date=June 14, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68RPblIak?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-18449711 |archivedate=15 June 2012 |accessdate=15 June 2012 |quote=One motif – a faint red dot – is said to be more than 40,000 years old. |df= }}</ref> * [[Font-de-Gaume]] in south-west France contains over 200 polychrome paintings and engravings from artists who worked over 17,000 years ago. The cave's most famous painting is a frieze of five bison, although renditions of many other animals, including wolves, are featured. * [[Gabarnmung]] (Australia) – this rock-art site in the [[Northern Territory]] features the oldest artwork in Australia at over 28,000 years. [[Indigenous Australians|Aboriginal]] artists painted fish, crocodiles, people, and spiritual figures, mostly on the site's ceilings.<ref>Masters (2009-10-05).</ref><ref name="Jean">{{cite journal|last=Michel Geneste|first=Jean|title=Earliest Evidence for Ground-Edge Axes: 35,400±410 cal BP from Jawoyn Country, Arnhem Land|journal=Australian Archaeology|year=2010|volume=71|issue=December|pages=66–69}}</ref> * [[Caves of Gargas]], France, features numerous negative hand stencils, some with one or more fingers absent. * [[Kapova Cave|Kapova cave]] in southern [[Ural Mountains]] (Russia) – presently 173 monochromatic [[ochre]] rock paintings and [[charcoal]] drawings or their traces are documented, presenting [[Pleistocene]] animals and abstract geometric motives. They are about 18,000 – 16,000 years old, from Late [[Solutrean]] to Middle [[Magdalenian]]. * [[Lascaux|Lascaux caves]] (France) – contains some of the best known artworks of early painters, many of those portraying large animals. * [[La Marche (cave)|La Marche]] (France) – due to the style the legitimacy of the cave paintings here are in dispute. * [[Cueva de La Pasiega|La Pasiega cave]] (Spain) – an art gallery created in prehistoric times, the exhibition of artwork here runs for at least 120 meters. Contains ladder-shaped abstract drawings dated to older than 64,800 years and thus presumably the work of Neanderthal artists. * [[Les Combarelles]] (France) – two galleries showcase more than 600 engravings. The more-than-11,000-year-old artwork portrays such subjects as reindeer drinking water from the river that flows through the cave, [[cave bear]]s, [[Panthera leo spelaea|cave lions]], [[mammoth]]s, and various symbols.<ref name="Hominidés">{{cite web | title = Les Combarelles – Grotte – Eyzies-de-Tayac – Périgord – Dordogne | url = http://www.hominides.com/html/lieux/grotte-combarelles.php | publisher = Hominidés.com | language = French | date = December 2007 | accessdate =1 May 2011 }}</ref> * [[Malipo County#Tourism|Malipo]]'s 4000+ year old 'Great King' pictographs at [[Wenshan Prefecture]], [[Yunnan]], China. * [[Roc-aux-Sorciers]] (France) – a [[rock shelter]] famous for its 14,000-year-old relief wall carvings. * [[Rock carvings at Alta]] (Norway) – artwork includes images of [[Bear worship]]. * [[Rock art of Figuig]] (Morocco) – engravings from the [[Neolithic]] age. * [[Rock art of south Oran (Algeria)|Rock art of south Oran]] (Algeria) * [[Rock art of the Djelfa region]] (Algeria) * [[Rock art of the Iberian Mediterranean Basin]] * [[Saharan rock art]] – there are over three thousand known sites where artists carved or painted on the natural rocks of the central [[Sahara desert]]. From the [[Tibesti Mountains]] to the [[Ahaggar Mountains]], the Sahara is an [[open-air museum]] containing numerous works by artists of the era. * [[Santimamiñe|Santimamiñe cave]] (Spain) * [[Sydney rock engravings]] (Australia) – Contains around 1,500 pieces of [[Aboriginal rock art]], which date from 5,000 to 7,000 years old.<ref name="abhe">{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalparks.nsw.gov.au/things-to-do/walking-tracks/aboriginal-heritage-walk |title=Aboriginal heritage|work=Office of Environment and Heritage|publisher=[[Government of New South Wales]]|accessdate=7 May 2011 }}</ref> * [[Tadrart Acacus]] (Libya) – rock art with engravings of humans and flora and fauna, which date from 12,000 BCE to 100 CE. * [[Tassili n'Ajjer#Prehistoric art|Tassili n'Ajjer]] (Algeria) – over 15,000 pastoral and natural engravings; the earliest rock art is from around 12,000 years before present, with most dating to the 9th and 10th millennia BP or younger. * [[Toquepala Caves]] (Peru) – "Abrigo del Diablo" and the other caves contain at least 50 noted pieces. The artists used paint made from [[hematite]], and painted in seven colors with red being dominant.<ref>{{cite book|title=South American Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zu7iAAAAMAAJ|year=1976|publisher=Trade and Travel Publications Limited}}</ref><ref name="Whitley2001">{{cite book|author=David S. Whitley|title=Handbook of Rock Art Research|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WwWETYxlNRkC&pg=PA712|year=2001|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-7425-0256-7|pages=712–}}</ref>{{Sfn|Aldenderfer|1998|pp=56–57}}
== Figurines == [[File:Laténium-dame-Monruz.jpg|thumb|The [[Venus of Monruz]] is an 11,000 year-old stylized pendant, 18 mm in height.]] Prehistoric figurines made from stone, [[ceramic]] or other materials have been found around the world. Notable examples included the [[Venus figurines]] of [[Upper Palaeolithic]] Europe and female anthropomorphic figurines from [[Neolithic]] Southwest Asia and Eastern Europe.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TdKdDgAAQBAJ|title=The Oxford Handbook of Prehistoric Figurines|last=Insoll|first=Timothy|date=2017|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780199675616|location=Oxford|pages=|language=en}}</ref>
* [[Venus of Brassempouy]], also known ''Dame à la Capuche'' ("Lady with the Hood") is a fragmentary [[ivory]] figurine from 25,000 years ago. One of the earliest known realistic representations of a human face, the artwork is in the [[Musée d'Archéologie Nationale]] at [[Saint-Germain-en-Laye]], near Paris<ref>Inventory number 47 019.</ref> * [[Seated Woman of Çatalhöyük|''Seated Woman'' of Çatalhöyük]] is a baked-clay nude female form seated between feline-headed arm-rests which is missing its original head and right side hand rest (although reconstructions of the artist's possible intent have been added). Resides at the [[Museum of Anatolian Civilizations]] in [[Ankara]], Turkey. * The [[Venus of Hohle Fels]] is an [[Upper Paleolithic]] [[Venus figurine]] made of mammoth [[ivory]] that was located near [[Schelklingen]], Germany. It is dated to between 35,000 and 40,000 years ago,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.uni-tuebingen.de/en/news/press-releases/newsfullview-pressemitteilungen/article/es-muss-eigentlich-eine-frau-sein.html | title="It must be a woman" – The female depictions from Hohle Fels date to 40,000 years ago... | publisher=Universität Tübingen | date=July 22, 2016 | accessdate=July 26, 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011145105/https://www.uni-tuebingen.de/en/news/press-releases/newsfullview-pressemitteilungen/article/es-muss-eigentlich-eine-frau-sein.html | archive-date=2016-10-11 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref> belonging to the early [[Aurignacian]], at the very beginning of the [[Upper Paleolithic]], which is associated with the earliest presence of ''[[Cro-Magnon]]'' in [[Paleolithic Europe|Europe]]. This female figure is the oldest undisputed example of a depiction of a human being yet discovered. In terms of figurative art only the lion-headed, [[zoomorphic]] [[Löwenmensch figurine]] is older. The [[Venus figurines|Venus figurine]] is housed at the Museum in Blaubeuren (Urgeschichtliches Museum Blaubeuren). * [[Venus of Dolní Věstonice]] is a Venus figurine, a ceramic statuette of a nude female figure dated to 29,000–25,000 BCE (Gravettian industry). It was found at the Paleolithic site Dolní Věstonice in the Moravian basin south of Brno, in the base of Děvín Mountain ([[Czech Republic]]). * [[Venus of Galgenberg]] * [[Venus figurines of Gönnersdorf]] * [[Venus of Hohle Fels]] * [[Venus of Laussel]] * [[Venus of Lespugue]] * [[Venus figurines of Mal'ta]] * [[Venus of Buret']] * [[Venus of Monruz]] * [[Venus of Moravany]] * [[Venus of Petřkovice]] * [[Venus of Savignano]] * [[Venus of Willendorf]] * [[Westray Wife]] {{wide image|Sleeping Reindeer - horizontal.jpg|1000px|''[[Swimming Reindeer]]'', a 13,000-year-old mammoth-tusk sculpture now residing in the [[British Museum]], depicts a female on the right and a male on the left.}}
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Art of the Middle Paleolithic]] * [[Art of the Upper Paleolithic]] * [[British Museum#Department of Prehistory and Europe|British Museums' Department of Prehistory and Europe]] * [[Cave paintings]] * [[Caves in Cantabria]] * ''[[Cave of Forgotten Dreams]]'', a 2010 documentary film about Chauvet Cave by [[Werner Herzog]]. * [[History of painting]] * [[Sculpture#Prehistoric periods|History of sculpture]] * [[Indigenous Australian art]] * ''[[Inside the Neolithic Mind]]'', 2005 book * [[International Federation of Rock Art Organizations]] * [[Blombos Cave#Ochre processing workshop|Ochre Processing Workshop]] * [[Pre-Columbian art|Pre-Columbian art in the Americas]] * [[Prehistoric art]] * ''[[Rock Art and the Prehistory of Atlantic Europe]]'', 1997 book * ''[[The Mind in the Cave|The Mind in the Cave: Consciousness and the Origins of Art]]'', 2002 book {{div col end}}
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
This is a '''list of video game publisher''' companies. A [[video game publisher]] may specialize in only publishing games for [[video game developer|developers]], or may either have in-house development studios or own [[subsidiary]] development companies. Some developers may publish their [[video game|games]] themselves. This list includes both active and inactive companies. Active publishers are either run independently or as a subsidiary of another company. Inactive publishers may either be defunct outright or still exist but no longer involved in video game publishing. {{Compact ToC|short1|name=Directory|top=no|refs=no|extlinks=no|seealso=yes|num=yes}} == List == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |+ Legend |- | Active independently |- style="background:#c9daff;" | Active as subsidiary of larger game publisher |- style="background:#ffe8a9;" | Defunct / no longer active in video game publishing |} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! scope="col" | Publisher ! scope="col" | Headquarters ! scope="col" | Est. ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notable games published ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| Notes |- id="0–9" | [[07th Expansion]] | data-sort-value="Japan" | [[Japan]] | 2002 | ''[[Higurashi no Naku Koro ni]]'' | |- | [[1C Company]] | data-sort-value="Russia, Moscow" | Moscow, Russia | 1991 | ''[[IL-2 Sturmovik (video game)|Il-2]]'' series
''[[Men of War (series)|Men of War]]'' series | Specializes in localization for Russia. |- style="background-color: #C9DAFF" | [[2K Games]] | data-sort-value="United States, Novato" | [[Novato, California]], United States | 2005 | | Also a video game developer, marketer, and distributor. Subsidiary and publishing label of [[Take-Two Interactive]]. |- style="background-color: #C9DAFF" | [[3D Realms]] | data-sort-value="United States, Texas, Garland" | [[Garland, Texas]], United States | 1987 | ''[[Duke Nukem]]'' series | Also a video game developer. Also known as [[Apogee Software, Ltd.]] |- style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | data-sort-value="3DO Company"| [[The 3DO Company]] | data-sort-value="United States, California, Redwood City" | [[Redwood City, California]], United States | 1991 | ''[[Army Men]]'' | Also a video game and [[video game console]] developer. |- style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | data-sort-value="4D"| [[The Fourth Dimension (company)|The Fourth Dimension]] | data-sort-value="UK, England" | UK | 1989 | ''[[Apocalypse (1990 video game)|Apocalypse]]'' | Also known as The 4th Dimension or 4D. Defunct in 2004. |- | [[505 Games]] | data-sort-value="Italy, Milan" | [[Milan]], Italy | 2006 | | Publishing division of Digital Bros. group. |- | [[5pb.]] | data-sort-value="Japan" | [[Tokyo, Japan]] | 2005 | ''[[Memories Off]]'' | Label of [[KID]] until 2006, and of Cyberfront since then. |- style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | [[7th Level]] | data-sort-value="United States, Texas" | [[Dallas, Texas]], United States | 1993 | ''[[Monty Python's Complete Waste of Time]]'' | Defunct in 1998. |- id="A" style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | [[Chuckie Egg|A&F Software]] | data-sort-value="UK, England" | [[Rochdale]], UK | 1981 | ''[[Chuckie Egg]]'' | Merged with [[MC Lothlorien]] in 1986 to become Icon Design Ltd. |- style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | [[Aackosoft]] | data-sort-value="Netherlands" | [[Zoeterwoude]], Netherlands | 1983 | Various [[MSX]] games | Defunct in 1988. |- style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | [[Aardvark Software]] | data-sort-value="UK, England" | UK | 1983 | ''[[Frak!]]'' | Defunct in 1989. |- style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | [[ABC Software]] | data-sort-value="Switzerland" | [[Buchs, St. Gallen]], [[Switzerland]] | 1991 | | Acquired by [[Electronic Arts]] in 1998. |- style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | [[Absolute Entertainment]] | data-sort-value="United States, New Jersey" | [[Upper Saddle River, New Jersey]], United States | 1986 | ''[[A Boy and His Blob: Trouble on Blobolonia]]'' | Defunct in 1995. |- style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | [[Access Software]] | data-sort-value="United States, Utah" | [[Salt Lake City, Utah]], United States | 1982 | ''[[Tex Murphy]]'' | Acquired by [[Microsoft]] in 1999; defunct in 2006. |- style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | [[Accolade (company)|Accolade]] | data-sort-value="United States, California" | [[California]], United States | 1984 | ''[[Hardball! (video game)|Hardball!]]'' series
''[[Star Control]]'' series
''[[Test Drive (series)|Test Drive]]'' series | Also a video game developer. Acquired by [[Atari, SA]] née [[Infogrames]] in 1999, name retired. |- | [[Acquire (company)|Acquire]] | data-sort-value="Japan" | [[Tokyo, Japan]] | 1994 | ''[[Akiba's Trip]]'' | |- style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | [[Acornsoft]] | data-sort-value="UK, England" | [[Cambridge, England]], UK | 1980 | Various [[Acorn Electron]] games | Rights sold to [[Superior Software]] in 1986. |- style="background-color: #FFE8A9" | [[Acclaim Entertainment]] | data-sort-value="United States, New York, Glen Cove" | [[Glen Cove, New York]], United States | 1987 | ''[[Turok]]''
''[[Burnout (series)|Burnout]]''

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}}
{{Infobox artist |name = Mabel Pakenham-Walsh |image = Portrait--Mabel Pakehham Walsh.jpg |caption = The artist in 2012 with sculpture, ''Leg of Bont'' |birth_name =Mabel Pakehham-Walsh |birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1922|9|}} |birth_place = [[Lancaster, England|Lancaster]], England |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2013|8|19|1937|9|}} |death_place = [[Aberystwyth]], Wales |nationality = British |field = Sculpture, Painting, Drawing }}
'''Mabel Pakenham-Walsh''' (2 September 1937 − 19 August 2013)<ref name="Cambrian News obituary">{{cite news |title=Cambrian News Obituary |access-date=7 August 2016 |url=https://www.ceredigion.gov.uk/utilities/action/act_download.cfm?mediaid=49747&langtoken=eng }}</ref><ref name="WikiTree records">{{cite web |url=http://www.wikitree.com/wiki/Pakenham-Walsh-21#R-1844632260 |title=Mabel Pakenham-Walsh |publisher=WikiTree |access-date=12 August 2016}}</ref> was a British painter, sculptor and designer,<ref name="Aberystwyth University">{{cite web|url=http://museum.aber.ac.uk/person/782 |title=School of Art collections biography |publisher=Aberystwyth University |access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref> and pioneering [[Women artists|female artist]]{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}<!-- WP:RS needed; removed link to WP:SPS (Twitter, FB, WP)--> in post-war European figurative art. She worked in many mediums, but is particularly well known for her colourful wooden relief sculptures.<ref name="Mabel Pakenham-Walsh A Retrospective video">{{cite AV media |people=Telfer, Pete (Director); Briggs, Alice (Interviewer); Szinner, Christine (Research Intern) |year=2012 |title=Mabel Pakenham-Walsh A Retrospective |medium=video |url=https://vimeo.com/178803789 |access-date=14 August 2016 |publisher=Culture Colony}}</ref> Her work was significantly influenced by [[Tribal art|primitive]] and [[outsider art]], and created primarily from recycled materials,<ref name="Cambrian News obituary" /><ref name="Aberystwyth University" /><ref name="Ceredigion Museum FaceBook">{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/ceredigionmuseum/photos/a.353760721356983.78559.211333315599725/353761651356890/?type=3&theater |title=Ceredigion Museum FaceBook page |publisher=Ceredigion Museum |access-date=11 August 2016}}</ref><ref name="Guardian obituary">{{cite news |last=Evans |first=Stuart |title=Mabel Pakenham-Walsh obituary |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2013/sep/15/mabel-pakenham-walsh-obituary| work=The Guardian |date=15 September 2013 |access-date=6 August 2016}}</ref> earning her recognition as an early [[Ecological art|eco artist]].<ref name="Ceredigion Museum FaceBook" />
==Life==
Mabel Pakenham-Walsh was born in Lancaster, England,<ref name="Cambrian News Biographical article">{{cite news |last=McNicholls |first=Julie |title=I cheated death five times... |url=https://www.ceredigion.gov.uk/utilities/action/act_download.cfm?mediaid=38478&langtoken=eng| agency=Cambrian News |date=2 February 2006 |access-date=7 August 2016}}</ref> the daughter of Robert Pakenham-Walsh,<ref name= "MyHeritage record">{{cite web |url=https://www.myheritage.com/names/mabel_pakenham-walsh |title=Historical record |publisher=MyHeritage |access-date=7 August 2016}}</ref> a prominent psychiatrist.<ref name="Cambrian News obituary" /> Born with congenital [[hip dysplasia]], she suffered lifelong physical disability; and in 1957, while a student at university, she was badly injured in a major car accident which compounded her disability.<ref name="Ceredigion Museum FaceBook" /><ref name="Mabel Pakenham-Walsh A Retrospective video" /><ref name="Guardian obituary" /><ref name="Cambrian News Biographical article" /> Consequently, Pakenham-Walsh campaigned throughout her life for disability rights,<ref name="Guardian obituary" /> especially for children and youths, ultimately leaving a legacy with the [[Snowdon Trust]] to assist disabled students in future.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.snowdontrust.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/2012-Review-spread-web.pdf |title=2012 Annual Review |publisher=Snowdon Trust |format=PDF |access-date=7 August 2016}}</ref> Pakenham-Walsh was active in the London arts scene throughout the 1960s and '70s, and befriended many significant figures, including [[Antony Armstrong-Jones, 1st Earl of Snowdon|Lord Snowdon]], [[Frances Bond]], [[Martin Leman]], Maeve and [[Mervyn Peake]], [[Wendy Ramshaw]], and [[Sir Tom Stoppard|Tom Stoppard]].<ref name="Archive Wales">{{cite web |url=http://www.archiveswales.org.uk/anw/get_collection.php?coll_id=848&inst_id=1&term=Pakenham-Walsh%20%7C%20Mabel |title=Mabel Pakenham-Walsh Papers |publisher=National Library of Wales |access-date=7 August 2016}}</ref><ref name="National Library of Wales">{{cite web |url=https://archives.library.wales/index.php/mabel-pakenham-walsh-papers-2 |title=Mabel Pakenham-Walsh Papers |publisher=National Library of Wales |access-date=13 August 2016}}</ref> Pakenham-Walsh also taught woodcarving classes to [[Further Education]] students in Kent, England.<ref name="Cambrian News Biographical article" /> In the late 1970s she moved to [[Aberystwyth| Aberystwyth, Wales]], where she continued to create, and became a local legend and beloved eccentric.<ref name="Cambrian News obituary" /><ref name="Letter from Aberystwyth blog">{{cite web |url=http://www.letterfromaberystwyth.co.uk/remembering-mabel-pakenham-walsh/ |title=Remembering Mabel Pakenham-Walsh |publisher=Letter from Aberystwyth |access-date=12 August 2016}}</ref>
==Education==
Pakenham-Walsh trained as an artist at [[Lancaster and Morecambe College|Lancaster and Morecambe College of Arts and Crafts]] (1954–58) and [[Wimbledon College of Art]] (1958-59).<ref name="Aberystwyth University" /><ref name="Guardian obituary" /> The writer and artist [[Mervyn Peake]] was an early mentor.<ref name="Cambrian News obituary" />
==Career==
From the beginning of her career, Pakenham-Walsh created drawings, paintings, and sculptures made almost exclusively from mundane and salvaged materials;<ref name="Cambrian News obituary" /><ref name="Aberystwyth University" /><ref name="Ceredigion Museum FaceBook" /><ref name="Guardian obituary"/> this unique strategy was borne of necessity as Pakenham-Walsh encountered "social barriers associated with being a female artist in the mid twentieth century, which made it difficult for her [...] to acquire raw materials for her art."<ref name="Ceredigion Museum FaceBook" /><ref name="Mabel Pakenham-Walsh A Retrospective video" /> Pakenham-Walsh's first published artwork was in the early 1960s when her [[Ballpoint pen|biro]] drawings appeared in the literary journal ''[[Transatlantic Review]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |jstor= 41512113| title=The Transatlantic Review No. 11, Notes on Contributors|registration=yes |via=[[JSTOR]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |jstor=41514022| title=The Transatlantic Review No. 12, Notes on Contributors|registration=yes |via=[[JSTOR]]}}</ref> At that time, she was employed as a designer at [[Pinewood Studios]], where she created set-pieces for major motion-pictures, including [[Cleopatra (1963 film)|''Cleopatra'']]; she also worked as a sculptor at [[Shepperton Studios]].<ref name="Cambrian News obituary" /><ref name="Cambrian News Biographical article" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.archiveswales.org.uk/anw/get_collection.php?coll_id=848&inst_id=1&term=Artists%20%7C%20Wales%20%7C%20Archives |title=Mabel Pakenham-Walsh Papers |publisher=The National Library of Wales |access-date=7 August 2016}}</ref><ref name="Cambrian News art show article">{{cite news |last=Davies |first=Clive |title=Woodcarving in Coalshed Brings Fame |date=1 January 1982 |access-date=13 August 2016 |url=https://www.ceredigion.gov.uk/utilities/action/act_download.cfm?mediaid=28070&langtoken=eng}}</ref> From 1965 to 1982, she exhibited at the [[Royal Academy Summer Exhibition|Summer Exhibitions]] of the [[Royal Academy of Arts]] in London.<ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Royal Academy Exhibitors, 1905—1970 Vol. 5 |location=The Getty Research Center |publisher=EP Publishing Limited |year=1981 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Royal Academy Exhibitors, 1971—1989 |location=The Getty Research Center |publisher=Hilmarton Manor Press |year=1989 }}</ref> During this era, select London artists rejected abstraction and conceptualism to pursue "the depiction of the human figure and everyday landscape";<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.getty.edu/art/exhibitions/london/inner.html |title=London Calling |last1=Brooks |first1=Julian |last2=Potts |first2=Timothy |website=getty.edu |publisher=Getty Publications |year=2016 |access-date=7 August 2016}}</ref> Pakenham-Walsh also sought to depict ordinary daily life, creating art that was both "playful and profound [to] invoke the [[Flow (psychology)|deep time]] of human nature."<ref name="Ceredigion Museum FaceBook" /> Pakenham-Walsh "exhibited widely in her lifetime in many art galleries and museums" worldwide.<ref name="Cambrian News obituary" /><ref name="Cambrian News art show article" /> Her work has been shown at the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]], and is held in numerous public and private collections, including: the [[National Library of Wales]], the [[Ulster Museum]], [[Aberystwyth University]], and the [[UK Craft Council]]; the actor and art historian [[Vincent Price]] and the photographer [[Antony Armstrong-Jones, 1st Earl of Snowdon|Lord Snowdon]] also admired and collected her work.<ref name="Mabel Pakenham-Walsh A Retrospective video" /><ref name="Cambrian News art show article" /><ref name="Good Reads article">{{cite web |url=https://www.goodreads.com/author_blog_posts/5690320-ten-to-one-author-interview---yasmin-ali |title=Ten To One author interview - Yasmin Ali |publisher=Good Reads |access-date= 11 August 2016}}</ref><ref name="Aberystwyth University archive">{{cite web |url=http://museum.aber.ac.uk/person/782 |title=Mabel Pakenham-Walsh |publisher=Aberystwyth University |access-date=12 August 2016}}</ref><ref name="Crafts Council">{{cite web |url=http://collections.craftscouncil.org.uk/results?mi_search_type=adv&mi_adv_search=yes&sort=1&maker_id=AUTH982 |title=Crafts Council Collections |publisher=Crafts Council |access-date=1 September 2016}}</ref>
==Selected solo exhibitions==
* 1984: ''Mabel Pakenham-Walsh: Painted Wood Carvings and Paintings'' at [[Aberystwyth Arts Centre]] (and tour of UK)<ref name="WorldCat record">{{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/mabel-pakenham-walsh-pren-wedi-ei-gerfio-ai-beintio-a-pheintiadaupainted-wood-carvings-and-paintings/oclc/501475077 |title=Mabel Pakenham-Walsh: painted wood carvings and paintings |publisher=Aberystwyth Arts Centre |access-date=13 August 2016}}</ref> * 2006: ''Drawings of Aberystwyth and Beyond'' at [[Ceredigion Museum]]<ref name="Cambrian News Biographical article" /> * 2012: ''Mabel Pakenham-Walsh: A Retrospective'' of carvings and drawings at [[Ceredigion Museum]].<ref name="Cambrian News arts article">{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Norman |title=Mabel has a Retrospective |url=https://www.ceredigion.gov.uk/utilities/action/act_download.cfm?mediaid=49713&langtoken=eng| agency=Cambrian News |date=23 February 2012 |accessdate=7 August 2016}}</ref><ref name="BBC Cymru Fyw">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.com/cymrufyw/16989979 |title=Celebrated artist and storyteller |publisher=BBC Cymru Fyw |access-date=13 August 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Art UK bio}} * [http://collections.craftscouncil.org.uk/results?mi_search_type=multi-tabs&tab=1&sort=3 Craft Council Online Collection: Mabel Pakenham-Walsh] * [https://vimeo.com/178803789 Mabel Pakenham-Walsh: A Retrospective, Video Interview (2012)]
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
The '''Michle Madonna''' is the work of an unknown sculptor called the "Master of the Michle Madonna" who probably worked in [[Brno]] or [[Prague]] during the second third of the 14th century. The name of the sculpture, brought from Brno in 1856,<ref>Hrabovská, 2008, p. 44</ref> relates to its non-original location in the parish church in Michle from where it was purchased by the [[National Gallery in Prague]]. [[File:Michelská madona, Národní galerie v Praze.jpg|thumb|''Michle Madonna'', [[National Gallery in Prague]]]]
== Description and context == The sculpture of the Michle Madonna is 120 cm tall and is carved from pear wood. It bears traces of polychromy. It is the most important example of the linear-rhythmic style of carving, dating from the second quarter of the 14th century in the Czech lands. This style is characterised by drapery that clings to a cylindrical torso in low, sagging pleats that have a decorative and finely drawn character, as does the linen cloth and locks of hair. The legs of the figure of the Madonna in [[contrapposto|contrapose]] are clearly distinguished between the standing and loose one. The child is resting on the Madonna’s jutting right side, towards which both the vertical and horizontal folds of the clothes converge, thus emphasising the bond between the mother and child. The lower position of the child enables the mother’s head to bow more, thereby making the sculptural composition more enclosed. The [[Christ Child|Infant Jesus]]’s hands have not survived but it is clear that he is making a [[blessing]], and is thus not turned towards his mother but towards the faithful.<ref>Hrabovská, 2008, pp. 18-19</ref>
The Michle Madonna’s formal conception has much in common with the linear style of [[Gothic art#Sculpture|French stone sculpture]] of the first third of the 14th century (such as the sculpture of five apostles from the Church of St Jacques-aux-Pèlerins and the tomb sculptures of French kings at [[Basilica of St Denis|St Denis]])<ref>Homolka, 2005, pp. 297-298</ref> that could have been mediated to the Czech context through the [[Rhineland]]. Sculptures of this style are typified by stylisation of shapes and a dense schematic linear pleating of the drapery in both standing and reclining figures. The objective details and wealth of decoration, precisely observed and reproduced, are striking. The group of wooden sculptures related to the Michle Madonna were also originally covered with polychromy, gilding and embossing.
The distinct abstracting style of the workshop of the "Master of the Michle Madonna" gradually absorbed the impulses of contemporary panel painting that was oriented more towards Italian models – the head of the Michle Madonna bears a striking resemblance to the "Madonna of Veveří". It was characterised by a greater emphasis on the physical volume of the figures and the realistic depiction of details. The workshop also produced other Moravian Madonnas (such as the "Madonna of Velké Meziříčí", the small "Apostle of Veverská Bitýška", the "Znojmo Madonna" and the "Prostějov Madonna"). Late works ascribed to the workshop of the "Master of the Michle Madonna" prefigured the abandoning of linear formalism that was accompanied by the effort to achieve specific form and greater naturalism.
== Notes == <references />
== References == * Fajt J, Chlumská Š, Čechy a střední Evropa 1220-1550, Národní galerie v Praze 2014, {{ISBN|978-80-7035-569-5}}, pp. 20–21 * Mistr Michelské madony - druhý život; Katalog vystavených děl Mistra Michelské madony, in: David Majer (ed.), Král, který létal. Moravsko-slezské pomezí v kontextu středoevropského prostoru doby Jana Lucemburského, Ostrava 2011, pp. 433–450, 451–472. * Tereza Hrabovská, Master of the Michle Madonna and his workshop, Bachelor´s dissertation, Catholic Theological Fac., Institute of the History of Christian Art, Prague 2008 (en. summary) * Jaromír Homolka: K některým problémům českého sochařství 14.století, in: Jan Royt/ Michaela Ottová/ Aleš Mudra: Regnum Bohemiae et Sacrum Romanum Imperium, Sborník k poctě Jiřího Kuthana, Praha 2005, pp. 297–298 * Albert Kutal, Jaromír Homolka: Mistr Michelské madony. Madona s dítětem a Apoštol, in: Jaroslav Pešina: České umění gotické 1350-1420, Praha 1970, pp. 127–132 * Albert Kutal: Sochařství, in: Jaroslav Pešina: České umění gotické 1350-1420, Praha 1970, pp. 113–114 * Albert Kutal: České gotické sochařství 1350-1450, Praha, 1962
== External links == * [http://www.rozhlas.cz/leonardo/historie/_zprava/tajemstvi-mistra-michelske-madony--863598 Secret of the Master of the Michle Madonna, Czech radio Leonardo, 2011]
